title: Can you write a sentence in English the way it would look now, 100 years ago, and 500 years ago? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Can you write a sentence in English the way it would look now, 100 years ago, and 500 years ago? I have been looking at language evolution recently and think it’s really fascinating. Is there a linguist who can write the same sentence in many forms of English stretching from now back til what would classify an “English Speaker” in the 1000s?If you could do this in any language it would be cool.” 1,000 years ago (maybe an Eastern dialect, not very influenced by Norse with full gender and case inflection). Andcwiss to þǣm frægne is earfedoe. þæt fragn is ne wénlicu. Middle English (using the dialect in Sir Gawain and the Green Knight): þe andswere to þis fraȝn is hard. þe fraȝn is noght stediȝ. 500 years ago: The answere to this frayne is hard. This frayne is not steady. 100 years ago: The answer to this question is hard. This question is not consistent. As for why, the question, and the question details say two different things. Additionally, the question is difficult to answer because English has always had different dialects, and until the last 400 years, authors with radically different spelling systems. I was totally guessing that the closest translation for consistent into Middle and Early Modern English was something like ‘steady.’ The word consistent didn’t pop up in English until the 1570s.

This is a page of a contract of marriage for one of my ancestors from the Isle of Man. A friend found it in the archives there. The document is dated 1654. I offered to assist in the transcription and was very surprised to find that, despite large differences in how the letters are written, the language is amazingly close to how we speak today: Here is my transcription (not translation). (2) It is conditioned, touched and agreed upon and faithfully promised and given by John Corrin, son of James Corrin, aforesaid, and by………………and……… do you, Margaret, sell, alienate, estrange all forever y(i)eld up, surrender and pass unto them, the said Henry Corrin (his uncle’s son) and Margaret Kegg (now to be his wife) and their issue their heirs Exetato et administrato (and) assigns forever irrevocable all the crop of corn or to that forever belongeth properly to said crops with the lands or ground that now is in the possession of Nicholas Corrin due to him the said John Corrin by heritage (inheritance?) or otherwise of the yearly rent of eight shillings six pence (single rent) to said Henry and Margaret and their issue after their yielding and paying the said rent with all services and impositions due to the lord of the ………(soyle?). Also the said John Corrin doth promise, engage and bind himself to enter the name of Henry Corrin, aforesaid, in the …(end of image) P.S. if there is an error, feel free to correct

I stand to be corrected, but here goes:  Now: “Can you write a sentence in English the way it would look now, one hundred years ago, and five hundred years ago?” -100y (c.1917): First World War “Can you write a sentence in English the way it would look now, one hundred years ago, and five hundred years ago?” -400y (c.1617): Just after the death of William Shakespeare “Canst thou write a sentence in English, in the wise that it looketh now, and look’d an hundred years past, and yet five hundred years past?” -500y (c.1517): Mary Tudor was one year old “Canst thou writ a sentence yn Englissh, yn such wise as yt seemeth nou, and seemed an hundred yeeres gonne, and fiue hundred yeeres gonne?” -600y (c.1417): A few years before the birth of William Caxton, the first Printer in England. “Canst thou wryt ane sentence yn Englische yn this wise: that as yt semeth nouwe, and hath semed an hundred yeres ygonne, and fiue hundred yeres ygonne?” -1000y (c.1017): Cnut is king of England, and marries Emma of Normandy “Meaht þu writan anne cwide in Ænglisc þus, swa he nu biþ, ond swa he hundred geara ær wæs, ond swa fif hundred geara ær?” (Edit: taking some suggested corrections from Ajax Blake and others.)

The Lord’s Prayer is a pretty good tool for linguistic comparison in the last two millennia. Christian missionaries have gone far and wide, learning local languages along the way, and it’s often one of the first things they translate. It also gets updated along with the text as languages have evolve. To wit: Old English: Matthew 6.9 (WSCp, 11th c.)Fæder ure þu þe eart on heofonum; Si þin nama gehalgod to becume þin rice gewurþe ðin willa on eorðan swa swa on heofonum. Middle English: Matthew 6.9 (Wycliffe's translation, c. 1380)Oure fadir that art in heuenes, halewid be thi name; thi kyndoom come to; be thi wille don in erthe as in heuene Early Modern Book of Common Prayer (1559)Our Father which art in heaven, hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done in earth as it is in heaven. Late Modern Book of Common Prayer (1928)Our Father, who art in heaven, Hallowed be thy Name. Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done, On earth as it is in heaven. (From: The Lord's Prayer)

Not an answer directly, but a comedy intrusion: The following is from the Washington Post Style Invitational contest that asked readers to submit "instructions" for something (anything), but written in the style of a famous person. The winning entry was The Hokey Pokey (as written by William Shakespeare). O proud left foot, that ventures quick within Then soon upon a backward journey lithe. Anon, once more the gesture, then begin: Command sinistral pedestal to writhe. Commence thou then the fervid Hokey-Poke, A mad gyration, hips in wanton swirl. To spin! A wilde release from Heavens yoke. Blessed dervish! Surely canst go, girl. The Hoke, the Poke -- banish now thy doubt Verily, I say, 'tis what it's all about. -- by "William Shakespeare"

Language hasn’t changed much in the last 500 years (1517 to 2017). Basic greetings have remained unchanged (Good Morning, for instance). Syntax may have changed a little but anyone today can still figure out the meaning (as, for example, with the famous soliloquy, in Shakespeare’s Hamlet — To be or not to be). You’ve said 100 & 500 years ago but you’ve also said the 1000s and 1017 would be 1000 years ago. The language was quite different then.

Now to 100 years ago would not differ other than as per idiom. But let’s try present, Shakespearian, Chaucerian, Late Anglo-Saxon. My name is Hans, as you know very well.My name is Hans, as thou knowest full well.I am ycleped Hans, as thou knowest full welle.Ic hat Hans, as thu knawest welle. I’ll check with a real linguist and am here beforehand excusing myself for not using thorn, yeough or eth in the last example : I could not find the ASCII. I could not find the ASCII.I could not finde the ASCII.I ne coud finden the ASCII.Ic ne cuthe finden tham ASCII.

MIDDLE ENGLISH, fourteenth century:"Men seyn thus, 'Send the wyse, and sey no thing'. Thou art so wys, it nedeth thee nat teche; Go, save oure lyf, and that I thee biseche ."MODERN ENGLISH, eighteenth century:"Men say thus, 'Send the wise and say nothing'. Thou art so wise, one needs not teach thee. Go, save our life, and that I beseech thee."MODERN ENGLISH, twenty first century { Go ahead. Try translating it into contemporary English. Do you catch the meaning? } Chaucer, THE CANTERBURY TALES, Sentences from The Miller's Tale

“The world is at all sixes & sevens.” (Used in 1598, or so. can you find the quote & the meaning? It’s still used, rarely, today.) “Every Tom, Dick, & Harry.” (A double-pun in about 1598 was used on this phrase.) I figure, 400+ years is close enough. Go back a bit further, and: “Who will bell the cat?” (About 1500, or so. Can you find the source for this one?) PS. Caxton had a great write-up on the problem with ordering “egges” one time in far southern England when the tavern lady didn’t understand the word. the solution? “eiern” … eggs in German!

Language may change backwards and forwards over time, but sometimes a language may undergo a catastrophic change , if it does not become extinct. This is usually due to major foreign influx ot domination. This happened to official ( Wessex)English, which was heavily inflected and more Germsnic after the Norman conquest and it did not recover properly until it became a socially universal official language again a few hundred years later. As well as this major social revolutionary change often gives a step change. This happened with English after the civil war when the second person singular ( thou etc.) was largely replaced by the plural (you etc) for example. And indeed French did not become standardised until the revolution. Otherwise a language remains relatively static. In fact American English has more similarity with early 18th century English than British English which has been subject to more stress and influence. Like anything it is difficult to predict how much the language will change in the future. If there is no catastrophic social change it is likely to remain the same, just as Icelandic is virtually old Norse.

I’d suggest you look at publications from those periods. Shakespeare and the King James Bible come close to 500. Chaucer is more distant and no longer fully readable for the general reader. Lots of freely available stuff at Project Gutenberg Online Book Cataloge. The problem with writing sentences is that new words are always entering the language. It is easy enough to mock up something that sound like Shakespeare or the King James Bible, but hard to avoid using words or phrases that did not come in till later. Likewise for early 19th century, or the later Victorian writing, itself nearly seven decades.

The thing is English in the UK has many regional dialects so you could write a sentence even today in many forms of ways. Don't worry, Divnt fecht ya sel, Ya nay wirry tha sen, git yar self nay fretn, Dinny git ya sell doon, Ach a vie a na mawpin aboot.

Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou? Tis better to giveth then to receive. A rose by any other name, would smell as sweet. If I was ta go din to the pond, I ’d sure as the sunrise, find a bonny lass sittin by the by.
